item.title: Live Updates: At Least 13 Are Killed as Fire Engulfs Hong Kong Apartments
item.description: Firefighters were still trying to extinguish the blaze at an apartment complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district.

item.title: Joan Branson, Richard Branson’s Wife of 35 Years, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Branson, the Virgin Atlantic founder, announced her death in an Instagram post.

item.title: The last time Hong Kong had a major fire was 2008.
item.description: The last five-alarm fire in Hong Kong engulfed a 15-story building in the Mong Kong district, killing four people.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Firefighters were struggling to bring the blaze under control in a densely populated complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district hours after it started.

item.title: Deadly Flooding in Thailand Prompts Rescues and Evacuations
item.description: The military sent troops, helicopters and boats to rescue stranded people. At least 33 people have been killed and more than two million displaced over the past week.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Pushes False Claims About Maduro
item.description: Opposition leader Maria Corina Machado faces criticism that she is exaggerating threats posed by Venezuela’s leader to justify U.S. force to overthrow him.

item.title: Jakarta Overtakes Tokyo as World’s Largest City, UN Report Says
item.description: The capital of Indonesia surpassed Tokyo as the world’s most populous city after the United Nations overhauled how it measures urban populations.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy, Former French President, Loses Corruption Appeal
item.description: France’s highest court has upheld a conviction against Nicolas Sarkozy, who led France until 2012. It comes weeks after he was jailed in a different fraud trial.

item.title: The Question Hanging Over Peace Talks: What Will Putin Accept?
item.description: A U.S. proposal may cross a number of red lines for the Russian leader, who sees little to lose and much potentially to gain from continuing to fight.

item.title: ‘Imperial Israel’ in the New Middle East
item.description: Despite a cease-fire with Hezbollah, almost daily strikes demonstrate an embolden Israel’s strategy to eliminate its enemies any time, anywhere.

item.title: Taiwan’s President to Seek an Extra $40 Billion for Military
item.description: President Lai Ching-te says the spending, which must be approved by the island’s legislature, would fund purchases of arms from the United States.

item.title: What’s Really Going On With Crime in South Africa
item.description: Police statistics in South Africa dispute President Trump’s claim that Afrikaners are being targeted in a genocide, but the high murder rate includes victims of all backgrounds. John Eligon, our Johannesburg bureau chief, traveled with several patrol groups in communities of South Africa to explore how the country is dealing with crime.

item.title: Trump Vowed Fewer Regulations and Lots More Oil. He’s Delivered on One.
item.description: The president’s energy strategy is projected to generate more pollution, but so far production has not risen significantly and price drops have been modest, analysts say.

item.title: Pope Leo to Visit Turkey and Lebanon
item.description: Leo XIV will meet political and religious leaders in Turkey and Lebanon, providing an early test of his geopolitical mettle. Here’s what to know.

item.title: Spat With China Becomes an Asset for Japan’s New Leader
item.description: Japan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, is not backing off from comments about Taiwan that enraged China. Many of Japan’s voters like her stance.

item.title: Violence Is Driving Catastrophic Hunger in Nigeria, U.N. Report Says
item.description: Africa’s most populous nation was already facing one of the world’s biggest hunger crises. It’s getting much worse.

item.title: Hamas Says It Returned Body of Another Hostage From Gaza
item.description: Israel confirmed the remains belonged to Dror Or, 48, who was abducted during Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks. The bodies of two captives are believed to be still in Gaza.

item.title: Crunchtime for Europe on Ukraine
item.description: President Trump’s peace plan is forcing the continent to confront some hard choices about military power.

item.title: ‘You Start Getting Desperate’: How It Feels to Be Young and Jobless in Britain
item.description: Rising youth unemployment is one of the challenges that will affect the success of the British chancellor’s economic approach as she unveils a crucial budget on Wednesday.

item.title: Australian Senator Suspended for Burqa-Wearing Stunt in Parliament
item.description: Pauline Hanson, the head of the far-right One Nation party, wore the garment as a prop to push legislation to bar it in public places.

item.title: Penny Oleksiak, Canadian Swimmer, Faces 2-Year Ban Over Antidoping Testing Rules
item.description: Penny Oleksiak, 25, who has won seven Olympic medals, was sanctioned under antidoping rules. Her suspension ends before the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.

item.title: Thomas King, Award-Winning Canadian Author, Says He Is Not Indigenous
item.description: Thomas King said he felt “ripped in half” on learning he had no Indigenous ancestry. The Canadian author has dedicated his career to writing about Indigenous people.

item.title: The 2026 Putin Calendar Is Here: ‘ A Man for Every Season’
item.description: January shows the Russian leader astride a snowmobile. For February, he flips a judo partner. In August, he offers advice: “My recipe for energy: Sleep little, work a lot and don’t whine.”

item.title: Volcano in Ethiopia Spews Ash Into Asia, Disrupting Flights
item.description: The ash cloud drifted over northern India, causing some flight delays and cancellations, and continued toward China.

item.title: Mapping the Brain’s Sense of What Goes On Inside the Body
item.description: Scientists are learning how the brain knows what’s happening throughout the body, and how that process might go awry in some psychiatric disorders.

item.title: BBC Accused of Censoring Trump by Dutch Historian Rutger Bregman
item.description: Rutger Bregman said his comment that President Trump was the “most openly corrupt president in American history” was removed before his lecture was broadcast on Tuesday.

item.title: Bolsonaro To Start Serving 27-Year Prison Sentence Over Coup Plot
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court ordered former President Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a prison term for conspiring to remain in power after losing the last election.

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Has Canadians ‘Elbows Up’ for Homegrown Wine
item.description: The trade war with the United States, bans on U.S. wine and liquor imports and a recent distributor strike in British Columbia have Canadians giving their homegrown wines another look.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine and Signals Resistance to Amended Peace Plan
item.description: The attack killed at least seven people in Kyiv, the authorities said, as Moscow suggested it would resist changes negotiated by Ukraine.

item.title: Minority Alawites Protest in Syria After Sectarian Attacks
item.description: The demonstrations followed unrest over the weekend in Homs, Syria’s third-largest city, which set off reprisal attacks on Alawites, a community once favored by the ousted Assad regime.

item.title: An Eritrean Woman Seeking Asylum in Canada Was Almost Deported From the U.S.
item.description: After more than 20 years in the U.S., an Eritrean mother and nurse tried to self-deport to Canada. She found herself in a Texas detention center instead.

item.title: At Miss Universe, Miss Norway’s Salmon Costume Steals the Show
item.description: The designer behind Miss Norway’s wild outfit was not surprised at the attention it received. “The original plan was to make noise.”

item.title: U.S. Plans Compounds to House Palestinians in Israeli-Held Half of Gaza
item.description: The project could offer relief for tens of thousands of Palestinians who have endured two years of war, but has raised questions about whether it could entrench the partition of Gaza into Israeli- and Hamas-controlled zones.

item.title: China and Japan, With Trump in the Middle, Are in a Showdown
item.description: With Japan’s new leader refusing to back down from China’s show of force and claims on Taiwan, Xi Jinping picks up the phone to try to pry the U.S.-Japan alliance apart.

item.title: Even the U.K. Prime Minister Can’t Resist ‘6-7’
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer egged on first graders doing the viral gesture, then apologized when told the school prohibited it. “I didn’t start it, Miss,” he said.

item.title: Four More Arrested in Connection With Louvre Heist
item.description: A Paris prosecutor said two men and two women were arrested as part of an investigation into the robbery at the museum.

item.title: Skye Gyngell, Chef Who Championed ‘Slow Food,’ Dies at 62
item.description: The Australian pioneer of sustainable cooking practices that preserved local traditions died in London. She had been diagnosed with aggressive skin cancer last year.

item.title: Warmed by Japan’s Support, Taiwan Takes Up Sushi Diplomacy
item.description: China closed off Japanese seafood imports after Japan’s new leader declared strong support for Taiwan. Suddenly, sushi is everywhere on Taiwanese social media.

item.title: Auto Industry Was Warned For Years of Poisoning, Sickness From Car Batteries
item.description: Despite decades of evidence on the toxic effects of lead battery recycling, companies opted not to act and blocked efforts to clean up the industry.

item.title: As Trump Pushes to End Ukraine War, Europe Toils to Have a Say
item.description: Initially cut out of development of the 28-point peace plan, European leaders are now trying to recast its pro-Russia slant. So far, it seems to be working.

item.title: U.S. Air Force Searches for Fallen Reaper Drone in Yellow Sea
item.description: The MQ-9 Reaper was conducting a routine mission when it fell into the ocean on Monday near a U.S. military base in South Korea.

item.title: Recycling Lead for U.S. Car Batteries Is Poisoning People
item.description: Recycling lead for U.S. car batteries is poisoning children — and we know because we tested them. Will Fitzgibbon, a reporter at The Examination, describes how children in Nigeria developed lead levels associated with lifelong brain damage, and how factory workers told us they were coughing up black dust.

item.title: Boeing Tackles Quality With a ‘War on Defects’
item.description: Two years after a panel flew off a 737 Max, Boeing is doing more inspections, completing work in its intended order and making other changes. Can the company keep it up?

item.title: BBC Chair Tries to Calm Political ‘Firestorm’ Over Trump Edit
item.description: Samir Shah defended Britain’s public broadcaster at a parliamentary committee hearing on Monday, while apologizing (again) for the misleading edit of a Jan. 6 speech by President Trump.

item.title: Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan as They Agree to Meet in China in April
item.description: In an unusual move, Xi Jinping, the leader of China, called President Trump. The two spoke about trade, Taiwan and Ukraine, according to separate official statements.

item.title: How the Peace Plan Looks to Ukraine and Russia
item.description: Our correspondents discuss the prospects for President Trump’s plan to end the war.

item.title: ‘Find a Job,’ Ontario’s Doug Ford Tells Protester As Bill 60 Passes
item.description: During a raucous hearing, the Ontario legislature passed a bill backed by Premier Doug Ford meant to expedite housing development and the eviction of tenants who are behind on their rent.

item.title: Gaza Humanitarian Foundation Is Closing
item.description: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation said it had succeeded in delivering million of meals in the war-torn enclave, but some Palestinians were killed trying to obtain them.

item.title: Army Chief Says France Must ‘Accept Losing Our Children,’ Igniting Uproar
item.description: The furor erupted as President Emmanuel Macron is expected to present a plan for paid, voluntary military service to bolster the armed forces against the threat from Russia.

item.title: Amid GPS and Ride-Hailing, the Allure of London’s Black Cab Endures
item.description: In a world of GPS and car-hailing apps, some Londoners still want to drive a traditional black cab. First, they must memorize thousands of city streets.

item.title: Grisly Killings of a Married Couple Spark New Sectarian Unrest in Syria
item.description: The government acted quickly to tamp down reprisals in the central city of Homs as it tries to manage repeated waves of bloodshed involving minority groups.

item.title: New Studies of Dog DNA Shed Light on Pets and People
item.description: New studies of canine genetics shed light on the diversity of dogs and our longstanding, still-evolving relationship to them.

item.title: Roya Mahboob Seeks New Ways to Educate Afghan Girls Under Taliban Rule
item.description: The entrepreneur Roya Mahboob is building off-line apps, underground networks and a global robotics team to educate Afghan girls unable to attend school.

item.title: Namibia’s New Minister of Health and Social Services Reimagines Health Care
item.description: Dr. Esperance Luvindao, who leads the country’s health and social services and is the youngest health minister in Africa, has ambitious plans.
